a-wee-journey.name: A Wee Journey
a-wee-journey.author: Nicolas “Niols” Jeannerod
a-wee-journey.kind: 32-bar jig for six couples in a six-couple longwise set
a-wee-journey.deviser-details:
This dance is written as a gift for Rachel Shankland and George Meikle that
took such good care of us during our Units 2 and 3. The changes of direction
give many opportunities for the men to flash their underwear as the RSCDS
demands for Unit 2.

instructions.content: All couples dance twelve hands round halfway to the left for six bars.

5th couple in second place and 2nd couple in fifth place cross by the
right hand, finishing in order 6, 5, 4, 3, 2, 1 with 6th, 4th and 2nd
couples on own sides facing down and 5th, 3rd and 1st couples on opposite
sides facing up.

All dance reels of six on the sidelines for six bars, giving right
shoulder to begin, finishing in order 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, facing in.

All turn by the right halfway to finish into allemande hold, 1st, 3rd and
5th couples facing up and 2nd, 4th and 6th couples facing down.

1st, 2nd and 3rd couples at the top and 6th, 5th and 4th couples at the
bottom dance circulating allemandes towards the top and the bottom
respectively, finishing in order 3, 2, 1, 6, 5, 4 with 2nd, 6th and 4th
couples on opposite sides.

All set. 2nd couple cross up while 3rd couple steps down; 5th couple cross
down while 4th couple steps up; 1st and 6th couples dance half right hands
across. All turn by the right and finish in order 2, 3, 6, 1, 4, 5 with
1st, 4th and 5th couples on opposite sides.

A reel of six is similar to a reel of four in that all dancers pass one
other dancer at each bar and take one additional bar to turn around at the
end. It takes twelve bars to dance a full reel of six, and six bars to
dance one halfway.

drawn-in.name: Drawn in
drawn-in.author: Shannon Kiernan
drawn-in.kind: 32-bar strathspey for three couples in a four-couple longwise set

instructions.content:
1st couple, giving right hands, dance a half figure of eight around 2nd
couple. 1st man giving left hand to 2nd woman, and 1st woman giving right
hand to 2nd man, turn once round.
1st couple dance in and cast off to second place.

1st couple, giving both hands, turn once and a half, while 2nd and 3rd
couples chase clockwise halfway.

1st couple, giving right shoulder to third corner positions, dance reels
of three on the sides with 3rd and 2nd couples, finishing with 1st couple
passing left shoulder to finish facing first corner positions.

1st couple dance corner pass and turn with first corner positions, corners
turning with both hands halfway and, pulling back right shoulders, dance
out to the opposite corner position. 1st couple, passing right shoulders,
repeat with second corner positions.

emmy-and-matt-s-wedding.name: Emmy & Matt's Wedding
emmy-and-matt-s-wedding.author: Emmy Wilkinson and Matthew Stuart Dunn
emmy-and-matt-s-wedding.kind: Medley of 32-bar strathspey and 32-bar reel for four couples in a four-couple longwise set

instructions.content:
1st and 4th couples cast in four bars. 2nd couple step up and 3rd couple
step down on bars 3-4. 1st and 4th couples dance a half figure of eight
around 2nd and 3rd couples.
1st and 4th couples in second and third places dance set and rotate.
1st couple turn both hands one and a half times in four bars.

4th couple cross down to fourth place while 3rd couple cast up to second
place.
3rd and 1st couples dance a poussette right round.
1st couple dance a figure of love around the 3rd and 4th couples:

1st couple dance a half figure of eight, woman up between 3rd couple,
man down between 4th couple, finishing by meeting in the centre of the
dance and briefly touching both hands.

1st couple pull back left shoulder and cast, woman down and man up;
1st woman dances up between 4th couple while 1st man dances down
between 3rd couple; both finish in third place on own sides facing
out.

1st, 3rd and 4th couples dance a promenade chain progression, finishing in
order 2, 4, 1, 3, with 1st couple in the middle of the set, 1st man facing
3rd woman in fourth place and 1st woman facing 4th man in second place.

1st couple dance a half reel of four with 3rd woman and 4th man, passing
by the right to finish with 1st man facing 4th woman in second place and
1st woman facing 3rd man in fourth place.

1st couple repeat with 4th woman and 3rd man, finishing with 1st man
facing 3rd woman on the men's line and 1st woman facing 4th man on the
women's line.

1st couple repeat with 3rd woman and 4th man, finishing with 1st man
facing 4th woman on the men's line and 1st woman facing 3rd man on the
women's line.

1st couple repeat with 4th woman and 3rd man, finishing in third place on
own sides.

emmy-s-wedding.name: Emmy's Wedding
emmy-s-wedding.author: Emmy Wilkinson and Matthew Stuart Dunn
emmy-s-wedding.kind: 40-bar reel for four couples in a four-couple longwise set

instructions.content:
1st and 4th couples cast in four bars. 2nd couple step up and 3rd couple
step down on bars 3-4. 1st and 4th couples dance a half figure of eight
around 2nd and 3rd couples.
1st and 4th couples in second and third places dance set and rotate.
1st couple turn both hands one and a half times in four bars.

4th couple cross down to fourth place while 3rd couple cast up to second
place.
1st couple dance a figure of love around the 3rd and 4th couples:

1st couple dance a half figure of eight, woman up between 3rd couple,
man down between 4th couple, finishing by meeting in the centre of the
dance and briefly touching both hands.

1st couple pull back left shoulder and cast, woman down and man up;
1st woman dances up between 4th couple while 1st man dances down
between 3rd couple; both finish in third place on own sides facing
out.

1st, 3rd and 4th couples dance a promenade chain progression, finishing in
order 2, 4, 1, 3.

et-voila.name: Et voilà !
et-voila.author: Violaine Eysseric
et-voila.kind: Medley of 40-bar strathspey and 40-bar reel for four trios in a square set
et-voila.date-format:
during the teaching certificate class in weeks 1 and 2 of Summer School %year%
as a gift for Rachel Shankland and George Meikle
et-voila.deviser-details:
The candidates devised dances and created “The Doonhamers' Book”. This dance
is for twelve dancers as there were twelve of us; it also uses a lot of
formations included in the dances of Unit 2 – even if not always in the usual
way!

instructions.content:
The persons in the middle of all trios dance left hands accross in the
middle of the square and right hands accross back to original place while
the other persons dance eight hands round to the left and back.

1st and 3rd trios dance a reel of four accross the set. In each trio, the
person in the middle dances in tandem with the person on their right; the
person in the middle has the lead to start, and the lead changes halfway
in the reel. The tandems pass left shoulder to begin.

All trios dance anti-clockwise one place, finishing facing inside the
square.

All trios dance «modified set and link for three»: in each trio, the three
persons set; the person on the left dances in to finish facing out in the
position at the right of the trio; the person in the middle and the person
on the right cast off one place to finish in promenade hold in the
positions at the left and in the middle of the trio.

All dance «Schiehallion reels» all round; the dancers in promenade hold
sticking together as one unit.

instructions.text:
Repeat as strathspey and then as reel, twice. All trios progress by one
side of the square each time through as persons in trio get reordered: the
persons on the left, in the middle and on the right becoming the persons
on the right, on the left and in the middle respectively.

hello-goodb.name: Hello, Goodb
hello-goodb.author: Nicolas “Niols” Jeannerod
hello-goodb.kind: 24-bar reel for three couples in a four-couple longwise set

instructions.content:
1st couple cross by the right, cast off one place and turn by the left to
finish facing first corners.

1st couple set to first corner, set to each other, set to second corner,
and finish man between the 2nd couple facing down and woman between the
3rd couple facing up.

1st man with 2nd couple and 1st woman with 3rd couple advance for two
bars, retire for two bars. 1st couple turn three quarters by the right to
own sides.
2nd, 1st and 3rd couples dance six hands round and back.

in-strathspey-time-george-please.name: In Strathspey Time, George, Please!
in-strathspey-time-george-please.author: Shona Holmes
in-strathspey-time-george-please.kind: 32-bar strathspey or 32-bar jig or 32-bar reel for two couples in a four-couple longwise set
in-strathspey-time-george-please.deviser-details:
George Meikle played wonderfully for our Units 2 and 3, even if not always in
the tempo we wanted. This dance can be danced in your choice of tempo to
reflect this.

instructions.content: 1st and 2nd couples advance, retire and turn one and a half times.

1st couple, followed by 2nd couple, lead down the middle for three steps.
2nd couple divide to allow 1st couple through and both couples lead up. On
bars 15-16, retaining right hands, 1st and 2nd couple turn by the right to
finish on own sides. [see note below]
1st and 2nd couples dance the poussette.
1st and 2nd couples dance right hands across.

1st couple turn by the right to finish in second place on own side. 2nd
couple step up on bars 31-32. [see note below]

If danced in jig or reel time, the 1st and 2nd couples need to finish bar
16 in the middle of the set facing partner. After the poussette, 1st
couple is already in second position and they therefore do not need to
move down as they turn. 2nd couple do not need to step up.

la-ville-lumiere.name: La Ville Lumière
la-ville-lumiere.author: Nicolas “Niols” Jeannerod
la-ville-lumiere.kind: 32-bar reel for four couples in a four-couple longwise set

instructions.content:
1st couple set and cast off one place as 4th couple set and cast up one
place. 2nd couple step up and 3rd couple step down on bars 3-4.

1st and 4th couples dance right hands across to finish facing third
corners, that is, 1st man facing 2nd man with 4th man behind him and 4th
woman facing 3rd woman with 1st woman behind her.

“Dolphin corners pass & turn”: 1st man followed by 4th man and 4th woman
followed by 1st woman pass third corners by the right and change lead;
corners dance in and turn right hand back to place as 4th man followed by
1st man and 1st woman followed by 4th woman dance in and pass right
shoulders to face fourth corners. Repeat with fourth corners to finish 1st
and 4th couples in the middle of the set with both hands joined with
partner.
1st and 4th couple dance a poussette to finish in the order 2, 4, 1, 3.
All 4 couples dance eight hands round and back.

matt-s-wedding.name: Matt's Wedding
matt-s-wedding.author: Emmy Wilkinson and Matthew Stuart Dunn
matt-s-wedding.kind: 40-bar strathspey for four couples in a four-couple longwise set

instructions.content:
1st and 4th couples cast in four bars. 2nd couple step up and 3rd couple
step down on bars 3-4. 1st and 4th couples dance a half figure of eight
around 2nd and 3rd couples.
1st and 4th couples in second and third places dance set and rotate.
1st couple turn both hands one and a half times in four bars.

4th couple cross down to fourth place while 3rd couple cast up to second
place.
1st couple dance a figure of love around the 3rd and 4th couples:

1st couple dance a half figure of eight, woman up between 3rd couple,
man down between 4th couple, finishing by meeting in the centre of the
dance and briefly touching both hands.

1st couple pull back left shoulder and cast, woman down and man up;
1st woman dances up between 4th couple while 1st man dances down
between 3rd couple; both finish in third place on own sides facing
out.

1st, 3rd and 4th couples dance a promenade chain progression, finishing in
order 2, 4, 1, 3.

on-the-way-to-the-printing-shop.name: On The Way To The Printing Shop
on-the-way-to-the-printing-shop.author: Giulio Dujany, Pascaline Latour and Nicolas “Niols” Jeannerod
on-the-way-to-the-printing-shop.kind: 32-bar jig for three couples in a four-couple longwise set
on-the-way-to-the-printing-shop.deviser-details:
During Summer School 2019, we talked over lunch about the story of Niols
writing his tune “En marchant pour aller photocopier des trucs”. This led to
us devising this dance together to go along with it.

instructions.content:
1st couple lead down and up, finishing in 1st place in promenade hold. 2nd
and 3rd join in the middle of the set in promenade hold.

1st, 2nd and 3rd couples dance a progressive promenade, finishing with 2nd
couple in first place and 1st couple in second place in the middle of the
set facing their first corners.

2nd, 1st and 3rd couples dance corners pass and turn, finishing in order
2, 1, 3 on own sides.
2nd, 1st and 3rd couples dance six hands round and back.

one-blue-cloud-in-the-grey-sky.name: One Blue Cloud in the Grey Sky
one-blue-cloud-in-the-grey-sky.author: Claire Cunin and Nicolas “Niols” Jeannerod
one-blue-cloud-in-the-grey-sky.kind: 40-bar reel for three couples in a three-couple longwise set
one-blue-cloud-in-the-grey-sky.editor-details: This dance is a three-couple version of “Two Blue Clouds in the Grey Sky”.

instructions.content:
1st couple set, cast off one place and dance a half figure of eight around
2nd couple. 2nd couple step up on bars 3-4.

1st couple set, dance a half figure of eight around 3rd couple and set
advancing to finish facing first corners.

1st couple dance corner pass and turn with their first corners and repeat
with their second, third and fourth corners, finishing on their own sides
in second position.

1st couple set, cast off one place. 3rd couple step up on bars 35-36. 1st
couple turn right hand in four bars.

praha-matka-mest.name: Praha Matka Měst
praha-matka-mest.author: Nicolas “Niols” Jeannerod
praha-matka-mest.kind: Medley of 16-bar strathspey and 16-bar reel for three couples in a three-couple longwise set
praha-matka-mest.editor-details:
The title translates to “Prague, Mother of Cities” and refers to Prague's
motto during the twentieth century. It was a symbol of the mission of Prague
to protect the independence and prosperity of the Czecho-Slovakian state.

instructions.content:
1st couple set advancing and turn both hands, dance down the middle and
turn halfway with both hands to face down in promenade hold. 2nd couple
step up on bars 5-6. 2nd and 3rd couples join in on bar 8.

2nd, 1st and 3rd couples dance an allemande down the dance. On bars 15-16,
1st couple stays in the middle and set advancing to face first corners in
third corner position.

1st couple dance corners pass and turn and cast away: Same as corners pass
and turn, except that corners turn halfway right hand and cast away to
opposite positions. On bars 23-24, 1st couple slow down to finish in the
middle on own sides in poussette hold; 3rd man curves to stay in the
middle on own side; 3rd woman joins in in poussette hold.

1st and 3rd couples dance poussette and petronella: Same five first bars
as the poussette. On bar 6, 3rd and 1st couples dance a quarter. On bars
7-8, 3rd and 1st couples dance a petronella turn to opposite lines,
finishing with 2nd couple in first position and 3rd and 1st couples on
opposite line in second and third position.

spot-on.name: Spot on
spot-on.author: Shona Holmes
spot-on.kind: 32-bar reel for any number of couples in a circle around the room: women with their partner on their left.
spot-on.deviser-details:
Our lovely Unit 2/3 teacher Rachel Shankland started every day with a fun warm
up dance and often described our better moments in dancing and teaching as
“Spot on”. Thus, this easy warm up dance was born; the circles in bars 9-12
and 17-20 create perfect spots. Thank you Rachel!

instructions.content: All advance and retire.

All advance and men retire while women stay in the middle, pulling back
right shoulder to face out.

Women circle round to the left in the centre while men circle round to the
left from places, giving hands if possible. All finish facing new
partners.

All turn new partners by the left one and a half times to finish with men in
the centre facing out and women on the outside facing in.

Women circle round to the right from places, giving hands if possible,
while men circle round to the right in the centre. All finish facing
original partners.
All dance dosido with their original partners.
All dance dosido with the person diagonally to the left.

All take promenade hold with original partners and dance round the circle
anti-clockwise.

sunday-early-in-the-morning.name: Sunday, Early in the Morning
sunday-early-in-the-morning.author: Marie-Laure Barret
sunday-early-in-the-morning.kind: 32-bar strathspey for three couples in a three-couple longwise set
sunday-early-in-the-morning.deviser-details:
During the Saturday ball at the end of the first week of Summer School in St.
Andrews, I was asked if I wanted to write a dance for our tutor Rachel
Shankland and for our musician George Meikle. Thus, on the following morning,
at 6.30am, I started devising this dance.

instructions.content: 1st, 2nd and 3rd couples set and link.
All chase clockwise halfway round the set.
Repeat bars 1-8 from new positions.
3rd, 2nd and 1st couples set.

3rd, 2nd and 1st couples, giving right hand to partner, turn halfway,
release hands and, pulling right shoulder back, dance on a curve to own
sides of the set.
3rd, 2nd and 1st couples set.
3rd and 2nd couples dance the «rose progression»:

3rd man and 2nd woman set as 3rd woman and 2nd man change places right
hand.

3rd man and 2nd woman turn with both hands halfway as 3rd woman and
2nd man dance into their partner's place.

3rd man and 2nd woman cast into each other's original places as 3rd
woman and 2nd man turn with both hands halfway.

3rd man and 2nd woman dance across the set as 3rd woman and 2nd man,
pulling right shoulder back, cast out to the sidelines.

the-mall-in-st-james-s-park.name: The Mall in St. James’s Park
the-mall-in-st-james-s-park.author: Nicolas “Niols” Jeannerod
the-mall-in-st-james-s-park.kind: 32-bar strathspey for three couples in a three-couple longwise set
the-mall-in-st-james-s-park.editor-details:
The name was suggested by Christophe Schuwey in reference to the painting of
the same name by Thomas Gainsborough.

instructions.content:
1st couple set, cross right hand, cast off one place, advance in the
middle and pull right shoulder to face first corners. 2nd couple step up
on bars 5-6.

1st couple turn first corners both hands, pass each other right shoulder,
turn second corners both hands and pass each other right shoulder to
finish on own sides facing out.

2nd, 1st and 3rd couples dance parallel reels of three in six bars on the
lines, 1st man giving left shoulder to 3rd man and 1st woman giving right
shoulder to 3rd woman. On bars 23-24, 1st and 3rd men exchange place left
shoulder while 1st and 3rd women exchange place right shoulder.
3rd and 1st couples dance the Poussette.

the-reel-of-the-51st-confusion.name: The Reel of the 51st Confusion
the-reel-of-the-51st-confusion.author: Anne Lanvin, Corentin Lefèvre, Isabelle Herlant, Louise Baltera, Nicolas “Niols” Jeannerod and Victor Lanvin
the-reel-of-the-51st-confusion.kind: 32-bar reel for three couples in a three-couple longwise set
the-reel-of-the-51st-confusion.editor-details:
This dance is a variation of one of the most popular Scottish country dances,
“The Reel of the 51st Division”.

instructions.content:
1st couple set, cast off two places and lead up, finishing back to back
facing first corners. 2nd couple step up on bars 3-4.

1st couple set to first corners and turn by the right halfway with them.
First corners give left hands in the middle and 1st couple and first
corners balance in line; first corners turn by the left three quarters to
end up back to back in the middle, facing second corners.

Repeat with first and second corners. On bars 23-24, second corners turn
by the left one quarter to opposite sides, finishing with 1st, 2nd and 3rd
women on opposite lines in 1st, 2nd and 3rd positions and 2nd, 3rd and 1st
men on opposite lines in 1st, 2nd and 3rd positions.
All dance six hands round and back.

Remember the person that is at the left of your partner from your point of
view: First, third and fifth times, you will start dancing with your
partner on your original lines; Second, fourth and sixth times, you will
start dancing with that other person on the opposite lines.

the-terrific-twelve.name: The Terrific Twelve
the-terrific-twelve.author: Kristian Vestli
the-terrific-twelve.kind: 40-bar reel for six couples in a six-couple longwise set
the-terrific-twelve.deviser-details:
The team of twelve candidates for our units 2 & 3 were terrific. In this dance
you hardly get a rest, to remind us of all the hard work we put in, but also
all the fun we had with our tutor, Rachel Shankland and our musician, George
Meikle.

instructions.content:
1st man with 2nd woman, and at the same time 2nd man with 3rd woman, 3rd
man with 4th woman, 4th man with 5th woman and 5th man with 6th woman turn
with the right hand.

All turn their partner with the right hand ending in allemande hold facing
up.

1st, 2nd and 3rd couples, and at the same time 4th, 5th and 6th couples
dance a three-couple allemande.

3rd couple with 2nd couple, and at the same time 1st couple with 6th
couple and 5th couple with 4th couple, dance right hands across and left
hands back, finishing in the middle of the set both hands joined.

3rd couple with 2nd couple, and at the same time 1st couple with 6th
couple and 5th couple with 4th couple, change places with a two-couple
poussette.
All circle twelve hands round and back.

the-waves.name: The Waves
the-waves.author: Saskia Frisby
the-waves.kind: 32-bar strathspey for three couples in a four-couple longwise set
the-waves.date-format: %at-date% and inspired by the waves in the sea around St. Andrews
the-waves.deviser-details:
For Rachel Shankland and George Meikle, with heartfelt thanks for their
kindness towards and patience with the Units 2/3 class of 2022.

instructions.content: 1st couple set.

1st couple dance a figure of eight around 2nd and 3rd couples on the
sidelines in six bars, dancing in and down to begin and touching nearer
hands when possible.
1st and 2nd couples dance the knot, retaining left hands.

2nd and 1st couples, giving left hands, dance four hands across once
round.

1st and 3rd couples dance four hands round to the left. At the very end of
this phrase, 1st and 3rd women as well as 1st and 3rd men release hands
while retaining hands with their partner.

1st and 3rd couples dance a poussette right round. On the first bar, 1st
and 3rd couples join both hands and turn into a diagonal line with 1st
couple above 3rd couple. The rest of the poussette proceeds as normal.

two-blue-clouds-in-the-grey-sky.name: Two Blue Clouds in the Grey Sky
two-blue-clouds-in-the-grey-sky.author: Claire Cunin and Nicolas “Niols” Jeannerod
two-blue-clouds-in-the-grey-sky.kind: 40-bar reel for five couples in a five-couple longwise set
two-blue-clouds-in-the-grey-sky.editor-details:
There exists a three-couple version of this dance, named “One Blue Cloud in
the Grey Sky”.

instructions.content:
1st and 3rd couples set, cast off one place and dance a half figure of
eight around 2nd and 4th couples. 2nd and 4th couples step up on bars 3-4.

1st and 3rd couples set, dance a half figure of eight around 4th and 5th
couples and set advancing to finish facing first corners, 4th woman and
2nd man for 1st couple, 5th woman and 4th man for 3rd couple.

1st and 3rd couples dance corner pass and turn with their first corners
and repeat with their second, third and fourth corners, finishing on their
own sides in second and fourth positions.

1st and 3rd couples set, cast off one place. 4th and 5th couples step up
on bars 35-36. 1st and 3rd couples turn right hand in four bars.

units-2-and-3.name: Units 2 and 3
units-2-and-3.author: David Osgarby
units-2-and-3.kind: 32-bar jig for three couples in a four-couple longwise set
units-2-and-3.deviser-details:
I devised this dance at the 2022 St Andrews Summer School while doing Units 2
and 3 of the RSCDS teaching certificate. The dance was devised such that the
2s and 3s are showcased representing Units 2 and 3. The vigour of the dance
represents the high level of effort put in by students during the course. Each
dancer dances from several positions, similar to how we have been taking the
position of different dancers to demonstrate formations. That the ones are
still during bars 9-24 represents spending time observing other dancers and
teachers during the course. The plentiful curving and casting to change
positions on the side lines was included to demonstrate good kilt control (or
lack thereof)!

instructions.content:
1st, 2nd and 3rd couples dance a «unit 3 lesson» from original positions,
finishing in order 3, 1, 2 with 1st couple on opposite lines.

1st couple position turn halfway by the right while 2nd and 3rd couple
positions set.

1st and 2nd woman positions cast down one place while 3rd woman
position dances in and up, curving into first place. In the meantime,
1st and 2nd man positions dance in and down one place, curving into
place, while 3rd man position casts up to first place.

2nd, 3rd and 1st couples dance a «unit 3 lesson» again from new places,
finishing in order 2, 3, 1 with 3rd and 1st couples on opposite lines.

2nd and 3rd couples turn partner halfway with right hands, and chase
around clockwise two places. 3rd and 2nd couples repeat four bars from
these positions, finishing in order 2, 3, 1 with 3rd and 1st couples on
opposite lines.

3rd couple, followed by 2nd couple dance a figure of eight down around the
1st couple and up the sides, finishing in order 3, 2, 1 with 3rd and 1st
couples on opposite lines.

3rd, 2nd and 1st couples dance a «unit 3 lesson» from new places,
finishing in order 1, 3, 2 with 1st couple on opposite line.

1st, 3rd and 2nd couples dance a «unit 3 lesson» from new places,
finishing in order 2, 1, 3 with all couples on own line.

a-jig-so-puzzled.name: A Jig So Puzzled
a-jig-so-puzzled.author: Nicolas “Niols” Jeannerod
a-jig-so-puzzled.content:
\relative f' <<
  \new Voice {
    \clef treble
    \key d \major
    \time 6/8

    \repeat volta 2 {
      \partial 8 a8 |
      fis4 d8 fis4 a8 |
      d8 cis b a4 a8 |
      b8 g b a g fis |
      e4. a4
      \bar "|" \break

      a8 |
      fis4 d8 fis4 a8 |
      d8 cis b a4 a8 |
      b8 g b a g fis |
      e4. d4
    } \break

    e8 |
    fis4 d8 fis4 fis8 |
    g8 fis e fis4 fis8 |
    g8 fis e fis e d |
    cis a cis e4
    \bar "|" \break

    e8 |
    fis4 d8 fis4 fis8 |
    g8 fis e fis4 fis8 |
    g8 fis e fis e d |
    cis4. b4
    \bar "||" \break

    e8 |
    fis4 d8 fis4 fis8 |
    g8 fis e fis4 fis8 |
    g8 fis e fis e d |
    cis a cis e4
    \bar "|" \break

    e8 |
    fis4 d8 fis4 a8 |
    d8 cis b a4 a8 |
    b8 g b a g fis |
    e4. d4
    \bar "|."
  }

  \new ChordNames {
    \chordmode {
      s8 |
      d4. d/cis | b:m a | g d/fis | e:7 a:7 |
      d4. d/cis | b:m a | g d/fis | a:7 d |

      b2.:m | e4.:m b:m | e:m b:m | a a:7 |
      b2.:m | e4.:m b:m | e:m b:m | a:7 b:m |

      b2.:m | e4.:m b:m | e:m b:m | a a:7 |
      d4. d/cis | b:m a | g d/fis | a:7 d4

>>

a-plane-from-reykjavik.content:
\relative f' <<
  \new Voice {
    \clef treble
    \key g \minor
    \time 4/4

    \repeat volta 2 {
      g4 d8. g16 bes,8. g'16 a,8. g'16 |
      g,4 \tuplet 3/2 { g'8 a bes } c4 \tuplet 3/2 { bes8 a f } |
      g4 d8. g16 bes,8. g'16 a,8. g'16 |
      \tuplet 3/2 { c,4 d ees } \tuplet 3/2 { d8 c bes } \tuplet 3/2 { c8 bes a } |
      \break

      g'4 d8. g16 bes,8. g'16 a,8. g'16 |
      g,4 \tuplet 3/2 { g'8 a bes } c4 \tuplet 3/2 { bes8 a f } |
      g4 d8. g16 bes,8. g'16 a,8. g'16 |
      \tuplet 3/2 { c,4 d ees } \tuplet 3/2 { fis4 g a } |
      \bar "||" \break

      bes4 f8. bes16 d8. bes16 f'8. f,16 |
      c'16 d ees8 d16 c bes8 a16 bes c8 f,4 |
      bes4 f8. bes16 d8. bes16 f'8. f,16 |
      c'16 d ees8 g4 f16 g a8 c4 |
      \break

      bes8. f16 \tuplet 3/2 { d8 ees f } g8. ees16 \tuplet 3/2 { c8 d ees } |
      f8. c16 \tuplet 3/2 { a8 bes c } f,4 a8. c16 |
      bes8. f16 \tuplet 3/2 { d8 ees f } g8. ees16 \tuplet 3/2 { c8 d ees } |
      f8. c16 \tuplet 3/2 { a8 bes c } bes4 bes |
    }
  }

  \new ChordNames {
    \chordmode {
      g1:m | g2:m f | g1:m | c2:m d4 d:7/fis |
      g1:m | g2:m f | g1:m | c2:m d:7 |

      bes1 | c2:m f4 f:7 | bes1 | c2:m f |
      bes2 c:m | f f:7 | bes c:m | f:7 bes |
    }
  }
>>

<<

      e d c b4. |
      c8 b a g a g |
      f e d c4
    } \break

    \repeat volta 2 {
      a'8 |
      g b d e c a |
      g b d g e c |
      f d b e c a |
      b c a g4 g8 |
      \break

      c,4 g'8 f4 a8 |
      g4 b8 c4 e8 |
      c a d b g c |
      c d b c4.
    } \break

    g8 a b c4. |
    f,8 e d c4. |

    f8 e g d4 g8 |

    c,4 e8 g4 c,8 |
    f g a g4 e'8 |

  \chords {

emmy-s-wedding-40bars.name: Emmy's Wedding (40-bar Version)
emmy-s-wedding-40bars.author: Nicolas “Niols” Jeannerod
emmy-s-wedding-40bars.content:
\relative f' <<
  \new Voice {
    \clef treble
    \time 4/4
    \key f \major

    \partial 2 f8 g a bes |
    \repeat volta 2 {
      c4 a8 f bes4 g8 e |
      f8 e f a c,4 c |
      bes'8 a bes d g, a bes d |
      c8 b c e g,4 a8 bes |
      \break

      c4 a8 f bes4 g8 e |
      f8 e f a c,4 c |
      bes'8 a bes d c b c e |
      f,4 f f8 c' d e |
      \break \bar "||"

      f8 c a' c, g' c, e c |
      d8 a f' a, e' a, c a |
      bes8 d c bes a g f e |
      e8 f g e bes'4 a8 g |
      \break

      f'8 c a' c, g' c, e c |
      d8 a f' a, e' a, c a |
      bes8 d c bes a g f e |
    } \alternative { {
      f4 f f8 g a bes |
    } {
      f4 f f8 c' d e |
    } }
    \bar "||" \break

    f8 c a' c, g' c, e c |
    d8 a f' a, e' a, c a |
    bes8 d c bes a g f e |
    e8 f g e bes'4 a8 g |
    \break

    f'8 c a' c, g' c, e c |
    d8 a f' a, e' a, c a |
    bes8 d c bes a g f e |
    f4 f f
    \bar "|."
  }

  \new ChordNames {
    \chordmode {
      s2 |
      f2 c:7 | f1 | bes2 g:m | c c:7 |
      f2 c:7 | f1 | bes2 c:7 | f c:7 |

      f2 c:7 | d:m a:m | g:m f | e:dim c:7 |
      f2 c:7 | d:m a:m | bes c:7 | f c:7 | f c:7 |

      f2 c:7 | d:m a:m | g:m f | e:dim c:7 |
      f2 c:7 | d:m a:m | bes c:7 | f f4
    }
  }
>>
emmy-s-wedding-40bars.composer-details:
I initially wrote “Matt's Wedding” as a wedding march-like strathspey for both
Emmy and Matt, and “Emmy's Wedding” as the companion reel for their medley
dance. At that point, the tunes were both named “Emmy and Matt's Wedding”.
Emmy and Matt later decided to refer to the strathspey and reel parts of the
medley as standalone dances and that is how the tunes got their independant
names.

emmy-s-wedding.name: Emmy's Wedding
emmy-s-wedding.author: Nicolas “Niols” Jeannerod
emmy-s-wedding.content:
\relative f' <<
  \new Voice {
    \clef treble
    \time 4/4

    \partial 2 f8 g a bes |

      c4 a8 f bes4 g8 e |
      f8 e f a c,4 c |

      c8 b c e g,4 a8 bes |
      \break

      c4 a8 f bes4 g8 e |
      f8 e f a c,4 c |
      bes'8 a bes d c b c e |
      f,4 f f8 c' d e |
      \break \bar "||"

      f8 c a' c, g' c, e c |
      d8 a f' a, e' a, c a |
      bes8 d c bes a g f e |
      e8 f g e bes'4 a8 g |
      \break

      f'8 c a' c, g' c, e c |
      d8 a f' a, e' a, c a |
      bes8 d c bes a g f e |
    } \alternative { {
      f4 f f8 g a bes |
    } {
      f4 f f
    } } \bar "|."
  }

  \new ChordNames {
    \chordmode {
      s2 |
      f2 c:7 | f1 | bes2 g:m | c c:7 |
      f2 c:7 | f1 | bes2 c:7 | f c:7 |

      f2 c:7 | d:m a:m | g:m f | e:dim c:7 |
      f2 c:7 | d:m a:m | bes c:7 | f c:7 | f f4
    }
  }
>>

I initially wrote “Matt's Wedding” as a wedding march-like strathspey for both
Emmy and Matt, and “Emmy's Wedding” as the companion reel for their medley
dance. At that point, the tunes were both named “Emmy and Matt's Wedding”.

en-marchant-pour-aller-photocopier-des-t.name: En marchant pour aller photocopier des trucs
en-marchant-pour-aller-photocopier-des-t.author: Nicolas “Niols” Jeannerod
en-marchant-pour-aller-photocopier-des-t.composer-details:
I wrote this tune during Summer School 2019. It was an assignment given by Ian
Muir as part of the course for class musicians. The week was very busy and the
only time I found to compose the tune while I was on my way to the centre of
St. Andrews to go print music sets.
en-marchant-pour-aller-photocopier-des-t.content:
\transpose a, d {
  \relative g' <<
    {
      \clef treble
      \key a \major
      \time 6/8

      \repeat volta 2 {
        \partial 8 b8 |
        cis8 a a a a gis |
        fis d d d d cis |
        b d fis gis fis e |
        e fis gis a b cis |
        \break

        cis a a a a gis |
        fis d d d d cis |
        b d fis e gis b |
        a4. a4
      } \break

      gis8 |
      fis cis cis cis b cis |
      fis d d d cis d |
      e b b b a b |
      cis d e fis gis a |
      \break

      fis cis cis cis b cis |
      fis d d d cis d |
      e b b b a gis |
      fis4. fis4 fis8 |
      \bar "||" \break

      fis' cis cis cis b cis |
      fis d d d cis d |
      e b b b a b |
      cis d e fis4 d'8 |
      \break

      cis a a a a gis fis d d d d cis |
      b d fis e gis b |
      a4. a4
      \bar "|."
    }

    \new ChordNames {
      \chordmode {
        s8 |
        a2. | d | b:m | e:7 |
        a2. | d | b4.:m e:7 | a2. |

        fis2.:m/cis | d | e | cis4.:m fis:m |
        fis2.:m/cis | d | e | fis:m |

        fis2.:m/cis | d | e | cis4.:m d/fis |
        a2. | d | b4.:m e:7 | a4. s4
      }
    }
  >>
}

flying-across-the-river.name: Flying Across the River

    } \break

    \repeat volta 2 {
      d8 |
      d g b c b a |
      g fis e d4 fis8 |
      e g b e d c |
      b a g fis4 fis8 |
      \break

      g fis e fis e d |
      e fis g d4 d8 |
      e fis g fis e d |

    }

  \new ChordNames {
    \chordmode {
      s8 |
      e2.:m | c4. d | e:m g/d | c b:7 |

forty-bars-of-clouds.name: Forty Bars of Clouds
forty-bars-of-clouds.author: Nicolas “Niols” Jeannerod
forty-bars-of-clouds.content:
\relative f' <<
  {
    \clef treble
    \key c \major
    \time 4/4

    c'4 c8 d e g,4 g8 |
    c b c d e d c b |
    d4 d8 e f a,4 a8 |
    d cis d e f e d c |
    \break

    c4 c8 d e g,4 g8 |
    c b c d e d c b |
    f'4 d8 f e4 c8 e |
    d4 b8 d c4 c |
    \bar "||" \break

    c8 b c d e g,4 g8 |
    c b c d e d c b |
    d cis d e f a,4 a8 |
    d cis d e f e d c |
    \break

    c b c d e g,4 g8 |
    c b c d e d c b |
    f'8 d a f' e c g e' |
    d b g d' c4 c |
    \bar "||" \break

    a'8 gis a b c e,4 e8 |
    a gis a b c b a g |
    g fis g a b d,4 d8 |
    g fis g a b a g f |
    \break

    f e f g a c,4 c8 |
    f e f g a g f e |
    gis e gis a b e,4 e8 |
    gis e gis a b a gis e |
    \bar "||" \break

    a8 gis a b c e,4 e8 |
    a gis a b c b a g |
    g fis g a b d,4 d8 |
    g fis g a b a g f |
    \break

    f e f g a c,4 c8 |
    f e f g a g f e |
    \tuplet 3/4 { b4 c8 } \tuplet 3/4 { d4 c8 } |
    \tuplet 3/4 { b4 c8 } b2 |
    \bar "||" \break

    c4 c8 d e g,4 g8 |
    c b c d e d c b |
    d cis d e f a,4 a8 |
    d cis d e f e d c |
    \break

    c b c d e g,4 g8 |
    c b c d e d c b |
    f' d a f' e c g e' |
    d b g d' c4 c |
    \bar "|."
  }

  \new ChordNames {
    \chordmode {
      c1 | s | d:m | s | c | s | d2:m c | g c |
      c1 | s | d:m | s | c | s | d2:m c | g c |
      a1:m | s | g | s | f | s | e | s |
      a1:m | s | g | s | f | s | e | s |
      c1 | s | d:m | s | c | s | d2:m c | g c |
    }
  }
>>

love-is-in-the-air-48-bars.content:
\relative f' <<
  \new Voice {
    \clef treble
    \time 4/4
    \key d \major

    \repeat volta 3 {
      \partial 4 a4 |
      d,4 fis8 a b4 a |
      b8 a b cis d4 d8 cis |
      b4 d8 fis b a g fis |
      e d cis b a g fis e |
      \break

      d4 fis8 a b4 a |
      b8 a b cis d4 d8 cis |
      b4 d8 fis b a g fis |
      e d e fis d4
      \bar "||" \break

      d8 e |
      fis4 a8 fis g fis e g |
      fis d b cis d cis b a |
      g a b cis d cis b a |
      a b cis d e fis g a |
      \break

      fis4 a8 fis g fis e g |
      fis d b cis d cis b a |
      g a b cis a b cis e |
      fis4 d d
    }
  }

  \new ChordNames {
    \chordmode {
      s4 |
      d2 g | a d | b:m e:m | a2 a:7 |
      d2 g | a d | b:m e:m | a2:7 d4

      s4 |
      d2 e:m | b1:m | g | a2 a:7 |
      d2 e:m | b1:m | g2 a:7 | d2.
    }

>>

love-is-in-the-air.name: Love is in the Air (32-bar Version)
love-is-in-the-air.author: Nicolas “Niols” Jeannerod
love-is-in-the-air.content:
\relative f' <<
  \new Voice {
    \clef treble
    \time 4/4
    \key d \major

    \repeat volta 2 {
      \partial 4 a4 |
      d,4 fis8 a b4 a |
      b8 a b cis d4 d8 cis |
      b4 d8 fis b a g fis |
      e d cis b a g fis e |
      \break

      d4 fis8 a b4 a |
      b8 a b cis d4 d8 cis |
      b4 d8 fis b a g fis |
      e d e fis d4
    } \break

    \repeat volta 2 {
      d8 e |
      fis4 a8 fis g fis e g |
      fis d b cis d cis b a |
      g a b cis d cis b a |
      a b cis d e fis g a |
      \break

      fis4 a8 fis g fis e g |
      fis d b cis d cis b a |
      g a b cis a b cis e |
      fis4 d d
    }
  }

  \new ChordNames {
    \chordmode {
      s4 |
      d2 g | a d | b:m e:m | a2 a:7 |
      d2 g | a d | b:m e:m | a2:7 d |

      d2 e:m | b1:m | g | a2 a:7 |
      d2 e:m | b1:m | g2 a:7 | d2.
    }
  }
>>
love-is-in-the-air.composer-details:
This is how I initially composed as an AABB 32-bar reel, before I presented it
to Violaine Eysseric who liked it and asked to use it for her dance “Love is
in the Air”. For her dance, I play this tune as ABABAB for 48 bars.

      s4 |
      d2 e | a a:7/cis | d a:7/cis | b/dis e |

matt-s-wedding-40bars.name: Matt's Wedding (40-bar Version)
matt-s-wedding-40bars.author: Nicolas “Niols” Jeannerod
matt-s-wedding-40bars.content:
\relative f' <<
  \new Voice {
    \clef treble
    \time 4/4
    \key f \major

    \repeat volta 2 {
      \partial 4 f4 |
      c4 f8. c16 a'8. c,16 bes' c,8. |
      e8. f16 g e8. bes'4 ~ \tuplet 3/2 { bes8 a g } |
      f8( f') e d c bes a g |
      g8. a16 g a8. g4 ~ g16 f e d |
      \break

      c4 f8. c16 a'8. c,16 bes' c,8. |
      e8. f16 g e8. bes'4 ~ \tuplet 3/2 { bes8 a g } |
      f8( f') e d c bes a g |
      g8. a16 g a8. f2 |
      \break \bar "||"

      f8 f' <a a,>4 <g g,> <e e,> |
      <d d,>4 <f f,> <e e,> <c c,> |
      <bes bes,>8 d c bes a g f e |
      e8. f16 g e8. bes'4 ~ \tuplet 3/2 { bes8 a g }
      \break

      f8 f' <a a,>4 <g g,> <e e,> |
      <d d,>4 <f f,> <e e,> <c c,> |
      <bes bes,>8 d c bes a g f e |
    } \alternative { {
      \set Timing.measureLength = #(ly:make-moment 3/4)
      f4 f f |
    } {
      \set Timing.measureLength = #(ly:make-moment 4/4)
      f4 f f2 |
    } } \bar "||" \break

    f8 f' <a a,>4 <g g,> <e e,> |
    <d d,>4 <f f,> <e e,> <c c,> |
    <bes bes,>8 d c bes a g f e |
    e8. f16 g e8. bes'4 ~ \tuplet 3/2 { bes8 a g }
    \break

    f8 f' <a a,>4 <g g,> <e e,> |
    <d d,>4 <f f,> <e e,> <c c,> |
    <bes bes,>8 d c bes a g f e |
    f4 f f
    \bar "|."
  }

  \new ChordNames {
    \chordmode {
      s4 |
      f1 | c2 c:7 | f1 | c2 c:7 |
      f1 | c2 c:7 | f1 | c2:7 f2 |

      f2 c:7 | d:m a:m | g:m f | e:dim c:7 |
      f2 c:7 | d:m a:m | bes c:7 | f2. | f1 |

      f2 c:7 | d:m a:m | g:m f | e:dim c:7 |
      f2 c:7 | d:m a:m | bes c:7 | f2.
    }
  }
>>
matt-s-wedding-40bars.composer-details:
I initially wrote “Matt's Wedding” as a wedding march-like strathspey for both
Emmy and Matt, and “Emmy's Wedding” as the companion reel for their medley
dance. At that point, the tunes were both named “Emmy and Matt's Wedding”.
Emmy and Matt later decided to refer to the strathspey and reel parts of the
medley as standalone dances and that is how the tunes got their independant
names.

matt-s-wedding.name: Matt's Wedding
matt-s-wedding.author: Nicolas “Niols” Jeannerod
matt-s-wedding.content:
\relative f' <<
  \new Voice {
    \clef treble
    \time 4/4
    \key f \major

    \repeat volta 2 {
      \partial 4 f4 |
      c4 f8. c16 a'8. c,16 bes' c,8. |
      e8. f16 g e8. bes'4 ~ \tuplet 3/2 { bes8 a g } |
      f8( f') e d c bes a g |
      g8. a16 g a8. g4 ~ g16 f e d |
      \break

      c4 f8. c16 a'8. c,16 bes' c,8. |
      e8. f16 g e8. bes'4 ~ \tuplet 3/2 { bes8 a g } |
      f8( f') e d c bes a g |
      g8. a16 g a8. f2 |
      \break \bar "||"

      f8 f' <a a,>4 <g g,> <e e,> |
      <d d,>4 <f f,> <e e,> <c c,> |
      <bes bes,>8 d c bes a g f e |
      e8. f16 g e8. bes'4 ~ \tuplet 3/2 { bes8 a g }
      \break

      f8 f' <a a,>4 <g g,> <e e,> |
      <d d,>4 <f f,> <e e,> <c c,> |
      <bes bes,>8 d c bes a g f e |
      f4 f f
    }
  }

  \new ChordNames {
    \chordmode {
      s4 |
      f1 | c2 c:7 | f1 | c2 c:7 |
      f1 | c2 c:7 | f1 | c2:7 f2 |

      f2 c:7 | d:m a:m | g:m f | e:dim c:7 |
      f2 c:7 | d:m a:m | bes c:7 | f2.
    }
  }
>>

michael-taylor-s-jig.name: Michael Taylor's Jig
michael-taylor-s-jig.author: Mikael Georgii
michael-taylor-s-jig.content:
\relative f' <<
  \new Voice {
    \clef treble
    \time 6/8
    \key bes \major

    \partial 8 f8 |
    d8 bes c d ees e |
    f8 g a bes c d |
    c8 g d' c g d' |
    c4. c8 bes g |
    \break

    a8 f bes a f bes |
    a8 g f ees d c |
    bes8 c d g d g |
    f4. ~ f8 ees c |
    \bar "||" \break

    d8 bes c d ees e |
    f8 g a bes c d |
    c8 g d' c g d' |
    c4. c8 bes g |
    \break

    a8 f bes a f bes |
    a8 g f ees d c |
    bes8 c d c bes a |
    bes4. r8 c bes |
    \break

    \repeat volta 2 {
      a8 f g a bes b |
      c8 b c d c a |
      bes8 c d f d g |
      f8 d ees f g bes |
      \break

      bes8 g bes c g cis |
      d8 bes f d ees f |
      g8 ees g a f a |
    } \alternative { {
      bes4. bes8 c, bes |
    } {
      bes'4. ~ bes4
    } } \bar "|."
  }

  \new ChordNames {
    \chordmode {
      s8 |
      bes4. bes/f | bes bes/d | c:m7/ees g:7/d | c:m c:7/e |
      f4.:7 f:7/c | f f:7/a | bes g:7/b | f f:7/a |

      bes4. bes/f | bes bes/d | c:m/ees g:7/d | c:m c:7/e |
      f4.:7 f:7/c | f:7 f:7/a | c:m f:7 | bes s8 c4:7 |

      f4. f/c | f2. | bes | bes/d |
      c4.:m/ees e:dim | bes/d g:7 | c:m7 f:7 | bes c:7 | bes
    }
  }
>>

    \break

    c4. a8 f4 e |
    d4 bes'8 g c,4 e |
    f2.

    aes4 f c2 |
    e4 f8 g aes8. f16 c8 aes' |
    g8. e16 c8 g' f4
    \bar "||" \break

    \key f \major

    c4 |
    c'4 a bes c8 d |
    c4. a8 f2 |
    g4 bes8 g e4 d8 e |
    c2. c4 |
    \break

    c'4 a bes c8 d |

    f2.
    \bar "|."

<<
  \relative c'' {
    \clef treble
    \key b \minor
    \time 4/4

    \repeat volta 2 {
      \repeat volta 2 {
        \partial 8 g'8 |
        fis8 b, b4 d8 b fis' b, |
        d8 b fis' b, a cis e g |
        fis8 b, b4 d8 b fis' b, |
        a8 b cis d cis d e g |
      } \break

      fis8 d b fis b fis d' fis, |
      e'8 a, cis a e' a, g' a, |
      fis'8 d b a fis g a b |
      a8 b cis d cis d e g |
      \break

      fis8 d b fis b fis d' fis, |
      e'8 a, cis a e' a, g' a, |
      fis'8 b, b4 d8 b fis' b, |
    } \alternative { {
      a8 b cis d cis d e g |
    } {
      g8 e cis fis, b4.
    } } \bar "|."
  }

  \chords {
    s8 |
    b1:m | b2:m a:7 | b1:m | a2 a:7 |

    b1:m | a2 a:7 | b1:m | a2 a:7 |
    b1:m | a2 a:7 | b1:m | a2 a:7 | a2:7 b4.:m
  }
>>

the-mall-in-st-james-s-park.name: The Mall in St. James's Park
the-mall-in-st-james-s-park.author: Nicolas “Niols” Jeannerod
the-mall-in-st-james-s-park.content:
\relative f' <<
  {
    \clef treble
    \key d \major
    \time 4/4

    \repeat volta 2 {
      a16 a8. a'8 a, fis'16 d8. d4 |
      cis8. cis16 cis8 d cis4 cis |
      b8. b16 b8 cis d e fis g |
      a,8. a16 a8 b a4 a |
      \break

      a16 a8. a'8 a, fis'16 d8. d4 |
      cis8. cis16 cis8 d cis4 cis |
      \tuplet 3/2 { b4 d g } \tuplet 3/2 { a,4 cis e } |
      d2 d4 d |
      \bar "||" \break

      fis,16 fis8. fis'8 fis, ais cis fis fis, |
      fis16 fis8. fis'8 fis, b d fis fis, |
      e'16 e8. g8 e \tuplet 3/2 { e b g } e d |
      cis d e fis g a b cis |
      \break

      fis,16 fis8. fis'8 fis, ais cis fis fis, |
      fis16 fis8. fis'8 fis, b d fis fis, |
      e'16 e8. g8 e \tuplet 3/2 { e b g } e d |
      cis8. a16 b8 cis d4 d |
    }
  }

  \new ChordNames {
    \chordmode {
      d1 | fis:m/cis | g | a |
      d1 | fis:m/cis | g2 a | d1 |

      fis1 | b:m | e:m | a |
      fis1 | b:m | e:m | a2 d |
    }
  }
>>

the-necromancer-was-me.name: The Necromancer Was Me
the-necromancer-was-me.author: Nicolas “Niols” Jeannerod
the-necromancer-was-me.content:
\relative f' <<
  \new Voice {
    \clef treble
    \time 4/4
    \key d \major

    \repeat volta 2 {
      \repeat volta 2 {
        \partial 8 e8 |
        fis4 g16 a8. g fis16 e g8. |
        fis4 g16 a8. b4. e,8 |
        fis4 g16 a8. g fis16 e g8. |
        fis8. e16 d cis8. d4.
      } \break

      fis8 |
      d'16 fis,8. fis fis16 cis'16 fis,8. fis fis16 |
      \tuplet 3/2 { d'8 cis b } a8. g16 fis4. fis8 |
      d'16 fis,8. fis fis16 cis'16 fis,8. fis fis16 |
      \tuplet 3/2 { g8 a b } a8. cis16 d4. fis,8 |
      \break

      d'16 fis,8. fis fis16 cis'16 fis,8. fis fis16 |
      \tuplet 3/2 { d'8 cis b } a8. g16 fis4. fis8 |
      \tuplet 3/2 { g8 a b } \tuplet 3/2 { a8 b cis } \tuplet 3/2 { d8 a fis } d8. d'16 |
      \tuplet 3/2 { d8 cis b } \tuplet 3/2 { a8 b cis } d4.
    }
  }

  \new ChordNames {
    \chordmode {
      s8 |
      d2 g | d g | d g | d4 a:7 d4.

      s8 |
      b2:m d/a | g fis:7 | b:m d/a | g4 a d2 |
      b2:m d/a | g fis:7 | g4 a d2 | d4 a:7 d4.
    }
  }
>>

the-pianist-in-black-and-white.name: The Pianist in Black and White
the-pianist-in-black-and-white.author: Nicolas “Niols” Jeannerod
the-pianist-in-black-and-white.content:
\relative f <<
  {
    \clef treble
    \key e \minor
    \time 4/4

    \repeat volta 2 {
      \partial 4 b4 |
      e8 fis g e b'4 a8 b |
      a8 g fis e fis d d' d, |
      fis8 d d' fis, e fis g e |
      b'4 a8 g fis a g fis |
      \break

      e8 fis g e b'4 a8 b |
      a8 g fis e fis d d' d, |
      fis8 d d' fis, e8 fis g e |
      b'8 a g fis e d e fis |
      \bar "||" \break

      g8 d b d g4 fis8 g |
      fis8 a g fis e c c' c, |
      e8 c c' c, d b g' b, |
      dis8 b a' dis, e d e fis |
      \break

      g8 d b d g4 fis8 g |
      fis8 a g fis e c c' c, |
      e8 c c' c, d b g' b, |
      dis8 b a' dis, e4
    }
  }

  \new ChordNames {
    \chordmode {
      s4 |
      e1:m | d | b2:m e:m | e:m b:7 |
      e1:m | d | b2:m e:m | b:7 e4:m d:7 |

      g1 | b2:m c | c g | b:7 e4:m d:7 |
      g1 | b2:m c | c g | b:7 e4:m
    }
  }
>>

the-sober-piper.name: The Sober Piper
the-sober-piper.author: Anne Lanvin
the-sober-piper.content:
\relative a <<
  {
    \clef treble
    \key a' \major
    \time 4/4

    \repeat volta 2 {
      \partial 4 e''4 |
      a,4 a8 cis e4 e8 fis |
      e8 fis a fis fis4 d |
      d, d8 fis a4 a8 b |
      a cis e cis d4 fis |
      \break

      a, a8 cis e4 e8 fis
      e8 fis a fis e4 cis |
      d e8 fis e fis e d |
      cis4 a a
    } \break

    e' |
    a4. cis,8 e4 a, |
    d8 cis b cis a4 cis4 |
    d,4 d8 fis a4 b |
    a8 cis e cis d4 fis |
    \break

    a4. cis,8 e4 a, |
    d8 cis b cis a4 cis4 |
    d e8 fis e fis e d |
    cis4 a a  e' |
    \bar "||" \break

    a4. cis,8 e4 a, |
    d8 cis b cis a4 cis4 |
    d,4 d8 fis a4 b |
    a8 cis e cis d4 fis |
    \break

    a,4 a8 cis e4 e8 fis |
    e fis a fis e4 cis |
    d e8 fis e fis e d |
    cis4 a a
    \bar "|."
  }

  \new ChordNames {
    \chordmode {
      s4 |
      a1 | a | d | d | a | a | d | a |

      a1 | a | d | d | a | a | d | a |
      a1 | a | d | d | fis:m | fis:m | b:m | a2.
    }
  }
>>

tiramisu.name: Tiramisu
tiramisu.author: Mikael Georgii
tiramisu.content:
\relative f' <<
  \new Voice {
    \clef treble
    \time 4/4
    \key a \major

    \partial 4 e4 |
    a8 gis a b a gis fis e |
    fis4 e8 cis a cis e cis |
    fis4 e8 cis a cis e cis |
    d4 b b4. e8 |
    \break

    gis8 a b a gis a gis fis |
    gis8 a gis fis e4 e8 fis |
    gis8 a gis fis e d b d |
    fis4 e8 d cis4 e |
    \bar "||" \break

    a8 gis a b a gis fis e |
    fis4 e8 cis a cis e cis |
    fis4 e8 cis a cis e a |
    gis4 fis fis4. f8 |
    \break

    fis8 gis a gis b a gis fis |
    fis4 e8 cis a cis e a |
    gis8 a gis fis e fis gis b |
    a4 e8 cis a e' fis gis |
    \bar "||" \break

    a8 gis a b cis b a gis |
    a8 b cis b a4 a8 b |
    cis8 b cis e d cis b a |
    gis4 fis fis fis8 a |
    \break

    gis8 a b d b a gis a |
    b8 d b a gis4 gis8 a |
    b8 a gis fis e d cis d |
    fis4 e8 d cis e fis gis |
    \bar "||" \break

    a8 gis a b cis b a gis |
    a8 b cis b a4 a8 b |
    cis8 b cis e d cis b a |
    gis4 fis fis fis8 a |
    \break

    gis8 a b d b a gis a |
    gis8 a gis fis e4 e8 fis |
    gis8 a b d cis b a gis |
    b4 a a
    \bar "|."
  }

  \new ChordNames {
    \chordmode {
      s4 |
      a1 | s | a | e2:7/b e |
      e1 | s | e | a2 a/cis |

      a1 | s | a | d |
      d2 dis:dim | a/e a/fis | e1 | a |

      a2 a/cis | a a/cis | a a/cis | d1 |
      e2 e/b | e e/b | b:m e | a a/cis |

      a2 a/cis | a a/cis | a a/cis | d1 |
      e2 e/b | e e:7 | e1 | a2.
    }
  }
>>

waltz-fur-j-i.name: Waltz for J. I
waltz-fur-j-i.author: Nicolas “Niols” Jeannerod
waltz-fur-j-i.content:
\transpose a, d {
  \relative f' {
    <<
      {
        \clef treble
        \key a \major
        \time 3/4

        \partial 2 e4 d |
        cis4. b8 a4 |
        a b cis |
        b cis d |
        b2 b8 a |
        gis4. fis8 e4 |
        gis a b |
        b cis dis |
        e
        \bar "||" \break

        e4 d |
        cis4. b8 a4 |
        a b cis |
        b cis d |
        b2 b8 a |
        gis4. fis8 e4 |
        cis' cis b |
        a2. |
        a4
        \bar "||" \break

        a4 gis |
        fis a cis |
        fis cis fis |
        d2 cis4 |
        b2 b4 |
        b d fis |
        b fis b |
        gis2 fis4 |
        e4
        \bar "||" \break

        fis4 gis |
        a4. b8 a4 |
        gis4. a8 gis4 |
        fis gis a |
        e2 d4 |
        cis4. b8 a4 |
        cis cis b |
        a2. a4
        \bar "|."
      }

      \new ChordNames {
        \chordmode {
          s2 |
          a2. | a/e | b:m | b:m/fis | e | e/gis | b:7 | e4:7
          s2 |
          a2. | a/e | b:m | b:m/fis | e | e:7 | d/a | a4

          s4 cis:m/gis |
          fis2.:m | fis:m/cis | b:m | b:m/fis | b:m | b:m/fis | e:7 | e4:7
          s2 |
          a2. | e | d | a/cis | a | e:7 | d/a | a4
        }
      }
    >>
  }
}

waltz-fur-j-ii.name: Waltz for J. II
waltz-fur-j-ii.author: Nicolas “Niols” Jeannerod
waltz-fur-j-ii.content:
\transpose a, d  {
  \relative f <<
    {
      \clef treble
      \key a \minor
      \time 3/4

      \partial 2 a4 b |
      c4. b8 a4 |
      b a g |
      a2 b4 |
      c2 d4 |
      e4. g8 e4 |
      d2 c4 |
      b2. |
      g4
      \bar "||" \break

      a4 b |
      c4. b8 a4 |
      b a g |
      a2 b4 |
      c2 d4 |
      e4. d8 c4 |
      b2 g4 |
      a2. |
      a4
      \bar "||" \break

      a4 b |
      c4. e8 g4 |
      a g e |
      g2. |
      e2 d4 |
      c4. e8 g4 |
      a g e |
      g2. |
      g4
      \bar "||" \break

      a4 b |
      c4. d8 c4 |
      b4. c8 b4 |
      a4. b8 a4 |
      g2 f4 |
      e4. d8 c4 |
      <<
        {
          b2 g4 |
          a2. |
          a4
          \bar "|."
        }
        \new Staff {
          \once \omit Staff.TimeSignature
          e'4 e d |
          c4 e g |
          c
          \bar "|."
        }
        \new ChordNames {
          \chordmode {
            g2.:7 | c | c4
          }
        }
      >>
    }

    \new ChordNames {
      \chordmode {
        s2 | a2.:m | g | a:m | f | c | g | e:m | g4:7
        s2 | a2.:m | g | a:m | f | c | g | d:m/a | a4:m
        s2 | c2. | f | g | c | c | f | c/g | g4
        s2 | a2.:m | g | f | e:m | c | g:7 | d:m/a | a4:m
      }
    }
  >>
}

waltz-fur-j-iii.name: Waltz for J. III
waltz-fur-j-iii.author: Nicolas “Niols” Jeannerod
waltz-fur-j-iii.content:
\relative f' <<
  {
    \clef treble
    \key e \minor
    \time 3/4

    \partial 2 e4 fis |
    g4. fis8 e4 |
    fis4 e d |
    e2 d4 |
    b4 e fis |
    g4. fis8 g4 |
    a4 g a |
    b2.~ |
    b4
    \bar "||" \break

    c4 d |
    e4. d8 c4 |
    d4 c b |
    c2 b4 |
    a4 g fis |
    g4. fis8 g4 |
    a4 g fis |
    e2.~ |
    e4
    \bar "||" \break

    e4 fis |
    g4. d8 b4 |
    c4 d fis |
    g4. d8 b4 |
    g4 e' fis |
    g4. d8 b4 |
    c4 d fis |
    g2.~ |
    g4
    \bar "||" \break

    a4 b |
    c4. d8 e4 |
    d4 c b~ |
    b2.~ |
    b4 e c |
    b4. a8 g4 |
    fis4 g a |
    g2.~ |
    g4
    \bar "|."
  }

  \new ChordNames {
    \chordmode {
      s2 |
      e2.:m | d | c | b:7 |
      e2.:m | d2 c4 | b2.:7 | s4

      s2 |
      c2. | g | a:m | d/a |
      e2.:m | d2 b4:7/dis | a2.:m/e | e4:m

      s2 |
      g2. | c2 d4 | g2. | g |
      e2.:m | a2:m d4 | g2. | s4

      s2 |
      c2. | d | b/dis | e:m |
      g2. | d2 d4:7/a | c2./g | g4
    }
  }
>>

winter-in-australia.name: Winter in Australia
winter-in-australia.author: Nicolas “Niols” Jeannerod
winter-in-australia.content:
\relative f' <<
  {
    \clef treble
    \key c \major
    \time 6/8

    \repeat volta 2 {
      \partial 8 g8 |
      g c e g, c e |
      a, c e a, c e |
      a, d f a, d f |
      g f e d c b |
      \break

      g c e g, c e |
      a, c e a, c e |
      a, d f a, d f |
      g f e d c b |
      \bar "||" \break

      g'4 g8 e4 e8 |
      gis4 gis8 e4 e8 |
      a g f a g f |
      a g f a g f |
      \break

      g4 g8 e4 e8 |
      gis4 gis8 e4 e8 |
      a g f g f e |
      d c b c4
    }
  }

  \new ChordNames {
    \chordmode {
      s8 |
      c2. | a:m | d:m | c4. g |
      c2. | a:m | d:m | c4. g |

      c2. | e | d:m | d:m |
      c2. | e | d4.:m c | g c4
    }
  }
>>
winter-in-australia.composer-details:
This tune is heavily inspired by “Christmas in Belgium” by my dear friend
Aymeric Fromherz.
